Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I think this timestep concept is an important issue to clarify.
 
There are several conceptualizations of timestep.  Most of these are L1
norms or Manhattan (taxi) distances, a form of counting linkages between
nodes.
 
1. The most basic assumption is that any signal to an input is
instantaneously propagated to an output in one step.  Any hidden nodes, and
their linkages are ignored. 
 
2. Next, the assumption that any propagation between any two nodes takes
precisely 1 step (which yields a form of graph diameter measure, still an L1
norm (count) between the input and output nodes). This is the layer concept
that Ken Stanley noted below.
 
3. There are recurrence cycle counts, which are probabilistic (frequentist)
distributions of L1 counts. These can be at the same layer, or cycles
between layers (the plot thickens).
 
4. There are propagation times that are L2 norms (Euclidean distances), say
time in microseconds between nodes or physical distances.
 
5. Then there are multiplicative combinations of 2 or 3 and 4.
 
6. Finally, there are the weighted propagation values - which can be a
weighted function on any of the above (see bias application)
 
It's been a while since I've looked at the NEAT codes, but as I recall NEAT
uses definition 2 in a greedy, Breadth First Search fashion, which is
consistent with MLFF. I could remember wrong, though.  See Dijkstra or
Bellman-Ford for other applications of "timestep" metrics.
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of Ken
Sent: Wednesday, February 03, 2010 11:17 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Timestepping through neurons in NEAT and HyperNEAT


  



Todd, while the first scenario you portray with the NEAT example sounds
right, I am having trouble understanding the second scenario that you
describe. That is, [0, 0.5, 1 , 1] is the coordinate of a connection, so I
am not sure what you mean when you ask if it is "input" first? Activation
travels down all connections in the same layer simultaneously in the same
timestep, and is summed at the target neurons. So order shouldn't matter,
though I may be misunderstanding.

One thing that I can answer is that links do not have state, though nodes
have state. However, like I said, I may not be understanding the question
fully.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "jtoddowen"
<jtoddowen@...> wrote:
>
> Please correct me if I'm wrong. My understanding of recurrence and
> neuron links in NEAT is that during each timestep new input data is
> presented to the ANN and travels to the next neuron until ultimately
> reaching the output. Therefore, using the NEAT structure at
> http://www.cs. <http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/neat.html>
ucf.edu/~kstanley/neat.html
> <http://www.cs. <http://www.cs.ucf.edu/%7Ekstanley/neat.html>
ucf.edu/%7Ekstanley/neat.html> it would take 3 timesteps
> for activation from input 1 to traverse neurons 16, 269 and then 5,
> although data is also going directly from 1 to 5 (through a direct link)
> in one step.
> 
> If the above is correct, how do the HyperNEAT timesteps work? Using the
> model from http://eplex.
<http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html>
cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
> <http://eplex. <http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html%20>
cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html%20> does [0, 0.5,
> 1 , 1] get input, then [0.5, 0, 1, 0.5] next? If so, it would seem to
> me the order you traversed the points in the substrate would affect the
> output. Or, do you keep the "state" of each link activation stored
> separately from one input substrate to another (one checkerboard play to
> another); in other words, are you keeping (4096 + 64) "states" for each
> timestep?
> 
> --Todd
>
